 CONSTITUTION OF VIRGINIA (June 6, 1776)

 DELAWARE DECLARATION OF RIGHTS (September 11, 1776)

 CONSTITUTION OF MARYLAND (November 3, 1776)

 That standing armies are dangerous to liberty, and ought not to be raised or kept up, without consent of the legislature.
 
 CONSTITUTION OF NEW HAMPSHIRE (June 2, 1784)
 
 A well-regulated militia is the proper, natural, and safe defense of a state.
 Standing armies are dangerous to liberty, and ought not to be raised or kept up without the consent of the legislature.
 
 Each of these statements represents an expression of a policy goal, a universally believed truth, if you will: “Standing armies are a threat to liberty, and we should whenever possible avoid them and rely upon a militia.” That is all they are. Does Cornell, for example, argue that these are something more than policy statements?

 Or, in the alternative, let us consider how the wordsmith we know Madison to be used the same phrase “the right of the people” in the 1st., 2nd., and 4th. Amendments. How do we justify reading the same phrase “the right of the people” to protect an individual right in the 1st. amendment, then translate it into a collective right in the 2nd. Amendment, to then be returned to protecting an individual right in the 4th. Amendment?
 
 The anti-federalists I quoted earlier opposed a constitution which permitted the federal government to create a standing army, which they viewed as the engine of despotism. They particularly objected to the additional exclusive grant of federal power to also arm and equip the state militias. The state militias were seen as the counterbalance to the threat of a tyrant making use of a federal standing army. They complained that the federal government could disarm the militias merely by refusing to exercise its exclusive power to arm them.

 "Let a regular army, fully equal to the resources of the country, be formed; and let it be entirely at the devotion of the federal government; still it would not be going too far to say, that the State governments, with the people on their side, would be able to repel the danger. Everyone, whether federalist or anti-federalist, knew Article 1 sec. 8 of the federal constitution granted exclusive and complete authority to Congress for arming the militias. The federalists argued the people are already armed and as such are capable if called by the state to defeat a tyrant. (See for example Noah Webster and Tench Coxe.) This was a well-founded argument, for everyone understood that this was already the primary source of militia arms at the time:

This argument failed to assuage anti-federalists fears, however, and this is why Madison drafted and our forefathers ratified a Bill or Rights recognizing specific individual rights like speech, press, religion, and yes, the RKBA. 
 
 The inclusion of the strongly preferred policy goal of relying on a “well-regulated militia” with the “right of the people to keep and bear arms” occurs because of the natural dependence of the one on the other: The “well-regulated militia” goal was ultimately dependent on the federal recognition and protection of the broader pre-existing individual RKBA. There is no credible evidence to suggest that the inclusion of this policy statement is the tail that wags the dog—it simply does not define and limit the individual right it relies upon for support no matter how much Cornell or others wish it to do so.

 I think we must agree to disagree over the implications of my historical analysis. In my opinion, the individual RKBA existed long before the nation was founded. The right did not contain a duty to provide militia service as condition for its free exercise. Nothing said by the founders indicates an intention to modify this broader pre-existing RKBA by limiting it only to a military service context. 
 
 But since the "well regulated militia" has proved an interesting topic to start the new year on, let us return to the specific militia power complaint of Patrick Henry:
 
 "A standing army we shall have, also, to execute the execrable commands of tyranny; and how are you to punish them? Will you order them to be punished? Who shall obey these orders? Will your mace-bearer be a match for a disciplined regiment? In what situation are we to be? The clause before you gives a power of direct taxation, unbounded and unlimited, exclusive power of legislation, in all cases whatsoever, for ten miles square, and over all places purchased for the erection of forts, magazines, arsenals, dockyards, &c. What resistance could be made? The attempt would be madness. Your militia is given up to Congress, also, in another part of this plan: they will therefore act as they think proper: all power will be in their own possession. You cannot force them to receive their punishment: of what service would militia be to you, {52} when, most probably, you will not have a single musket in the state? for, as arms are to be provided by Congress, they may or may not furnish them.
 
 Let me here call your attention to that part which gives the Congress power "to provide for organizing, arming, and disciplining the militia, and for governing such part of them as may be employed in the service of the United States - reserving to the states, respectively, the appointment of the officers, and the authority of training the militia according to the discipline prescribed by Congress." If they neglect or refuse to discipline or arm our militia, they will be useless: the states can do neither - this power being exclusively given to Congress. The power of appointing officers over men not disciplined or armed is ridiculous; so that this pretended little remains of power left to the states may, at the pleasure of Congress, be rendered nugatory."

 Cornell succeeded only in painting himself, and other deniers, into a corner. You must excuse me for coming back to this issue now, but I have been too busy to post for a few weeks and I wish to add my two cents on the Pennsylvania militia statute cited by Chester. 
 
 As I understand it, Chester took the following militia-related position within this thread (speaking, I presume, as a general historical proposition for all American Colonists):
 
 "IF you were a gun owner, which, as you say, nearly every male was, then you were required to muster in for training at dates and times specified. so that you could fit 2A's requirement that you be a part of a "well regulated" militia."
 
 Chester was thereafter challenged by another poster:
 
 "If this is the case, then you'll have no problem providing evidence of people being either forcibly disarmed by the government, or locked away in prisons, for their failure to partake in their required militia practices and duties."
 
 Chester's evidentiary reply was:
 
 "Realy?
 
 Try this statute from Pennsylvania: (cite omitted by Bryan)"
 
 I have taken the trouble to read the statute, and I must respectfully disagree with you, Chester. I do not believe this statute supports your position that militia service was a requirement of the individual RKBA. 
 
 The Act is unique. It has nothing to do with the individual RKBA. It is instead a war time measure which imposed a duty on every male to arm himself with a standardized set of military equipment (certain males were exempt) and thereafter to render militia service. The Act's preamble sets forth the emergency situation (my politically incorrect grade school textbooks called this the "French and Indian War"):
 
 "Whereas in this time of actual war with the French King and
 his subjects and his savage Indian Allies, it is absolutely necessary
 for the service of our most Gracious Sovereign...."
 
 But more importantly I found the militia enrolment list had nothing to do with gun owners. It did not mention gun owners at all, nor did it require or even imply a requirement of militia service as a condition of choosing to exercise your RKBA. The Act begins with nothing more than a simple census of every age-appropriate male--ordered performed by each county sheriff and his elected assistant; who in accordance with the Act:
 
 "shall take down in writing the names and surnames of every male person residing in the said township, boroughs or wards (servants and apprentices excepted) above the age of seventeen and under fifty-five years, noting against every name to what religious society each person belongs, especially such as are papists or reputed papists...."
 
 The Act then imposed a duty-irrespective of the individual RKBA-on each person so identified by the census (excluding the dreaded papists and the less dreaded conscientious objectors) to provide themselves with the following armament:
 
 "And be it enacted, That every of the persons so as aforesaid enrolled, not conscientiously scrupling the use of arms, shall be sufficiently armed with one good musket, fuzee or other firelock well fixed, a cutlass, bayonet or tomahawk, a cartouch box, filled with twelve or more cartridges of powder, twelve or more sizeable bullets, and three good flints, and shall appear and attend in their proper persons with the accoutrements, arms and ammunition aforesaid in good order, on the first Mondays in the months of June...."
 
 The Act further commanded that if any person appeared for muster without these items then he was subject to a fine-unless it appeared he was incapable of providing them for himself (ie. could not afford them), in which case if his hardship were believed then he was excused the fine and the state would provide the arms for him:
 
 "And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if the captain, lieutenant and ensign or any two of them, shall adjudge any person or persons enrolled as aforesaid, and appearing on the days of muster hereinbefore-appointed, to be incapable of providing and furnishing him or themselves with the arms, ammunition and accoutrements required by this act, every such person so appearing shall be exempt from the fines and forfeitures imposed by virtue of this act until such arms, ammunition and accoutrements shall be provided for and delivered to him."
 
 But regardless of whether he could afford them or got them as a state poor man's hand-out, each person enrolled was further obligated to keep these militia arms in his private residence and in a state of readiness: 
 
 "And be it further enacted, That every person so as aforesaid enrolled shall, at all times during the continuance of this act, keep by him in his dwelling house, the arms and accoutrements aforesaid in good order and fit for immediate service, in case of any sudden invasion, insurrection or rebellion, under the like penalty of four shillings for every such neglect or offense."
 
 I can find nothing in this act which supports the position that militia service was a condition of the free exercise of your RKBA. The act stepped outside the individual RKBA by first imposing a duty of universal and standardized military firearm ownership and then imposed a militia duty. 
 
 The act did not prohibit possession of any other arms not required for militia service, nor did it prohibit the possession of arms for private use-by Protestants, that is. Interestingly, the Act also required the complete disarmament of "Papists"-all arms and gun powder were prohibited to them, and they were required on penalty of imprisonment to surrender any firearms and powder they already held. In this sense the Act tracked exactly with the RKBA provision of the English Bill of Rights of 1689. 
 
 But the Act did nothing to touch the already privately held arms of Protestants-except for an attempt to recover the many militia arms which, having been previously bought at government expense, had apparently already been illegally misappropriated to private use (and here we thought this kind of thing only happened to government property sent for use in Iraq). 
 
 The Act did nothing to prohibit other purchases of firearms for private use. It did nothing to prohibit the required militia arms from being used in private concerns (such as hunting) so long as the arms were kept in a state of constant readiness for emergency militia use. The act most certainly did not focus on gun owners and impose upon them choice of accepting militia service or surrendering their arms. While the Act exempted persons other than "Papists" from militia service (those unfit and "apprentices", for example), the Act did not require them to surrender their right to keep and bear private arms as a result of failing to provide militia service. The Act merely took an extraordinary war-time emergency position of requiring that every capable male provide himself with an additional standardized set of military equipment-whether he is already privately exercising his RKBA or not. 
 
 Now, if we really want to know if the colonists were required to either accept militia service or surrender their RKBA, then we need to ask whether the government required those who had armed themselves pursuant to the Act to surrender their arms after the conclusion of the war and their militia service ended. We need to know whether the government forbad the possession of any other firearms not listed within the Act's military equipment list. We need to know whether the government prohibited these men from taking arms they purchased in a time of war and using them privately once peace was established. We need to know whether the government would have required men who "aged out of" the militia requirement to surrender all of their arms-or at least those listed as military equipment by the Act. This, perhaps, would be evidence of a desire to link the RKBA to a requirement of militia service, but such evidence does not exist.
 
 If my government today passed a militia act which enabled and required me to arm myself with an M-4 rifle and ammo and then required me to render militia service, then this would be an exercise of permitted governmental power. But there simply is no evidence, whether within the above-quoted militia act or from any other source, to suggest that exercising my RKBA by itself requires that I give militia service.
